name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

key_work.title: Jedda
key_work.credit_line:
Courtesy Chauvel Film Enterprises Pty Ltd

Jedda is held in the collection of the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
key_work.brief_description: Jedda is beloved by many First Peoples for being Australia’s first film with Aboriginal lead roles. But despite being a first for First Peoples representation, it also reflects deeply problematic times in Australia, characterised by policies of assimilation and forced removel of Indigenous children.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

links.description: Bruce McGuinness’ Blackfire is the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. Made in 1972, the film reveals the state of Indigenous politics and society in Melbourne and features appearances by country and Western legend Harry Williams and his son Bertie, who was one of the original founders of the 1972 Aboriginal Tent Embassy.

links.description: While Jedda was the first Australian-funded colour feature shot in the country, US production Kangaroo was the first to be shot in Australia in 1952. The American western starred Maureen O’Hara and Peter Lawford, as well as Indigenous actors Clyde Combo and Henry Murdoch.
